ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
What is your overall rating of the primary instructor?
The primary instructor's sensitivity to students and ability to provide students with adequate feedback was:

narratives.question_text: Indicate the total number of hours per week (outside the classroom) you spent on this course:
comments: 1 hr bi-weekly
1 hour a week
None.
none
1 to 5
There is no outside work for the seminar.

narratives.question_text: Looking back on this course, what is your overall assessment of the course:  What are its strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might it be improved?
comments: Strengths: very diverse and interesting

Way too heavy on the CDE, not enough on the SBS. Also, I realize this is a time for people to learn about research in the field, but for those of us who don't necessarily want to do research, talks from people like Tim Mercer are much more valuable. Please try and focus more on this side of public health in future seminars.
There was a variety of topics discussed, however, i think it may be more interesting to have more outside speakers who aren't necessarily affiliated with Yale.
I enjoyed this semester's topics
The lectures were interesting and informative.

The only thing I did not like about the seminar was that some of the invited speakers were faculty from whom we've heard many times talk about their research. Those topics weren't necessarily new and thus not very interesting and stimulating. I would like to see more faculty from different institutions or from other schools talking about a variety of topics.

I had heard at least one of the speakers in another course (Measurement Issues) so that lecture was a bit repetitive. Also, many of us had already taken the required SBS course with Jeanette Ickovics so hearing her lecture again was incredibly repetitive as her talk was not much different from her class! I preferred lectures from professors who did not teach required first-year courses or professors who did teach required courses but spoke about research they did not tell us about in their classes (eg. Rob Dubrow).
I do not feel that this course contribute substantially to my education at YSPH.
Speakers were Epi driven, I would have appreciated more SBS speakers throughout the year.
The seminars were very interesting.

There was interesting mix of speakers this semester. I really enjoyed having lunch with Jewel Mullen.It would be neat if we could suggest and have other outside speakers brought in. I am not sure if there is funding for this.

The spectrum of topics covered in seminar is very broad. Some were more enjoyable to me than others perhaps due to interest but also mainly due to the nature of the speaker. Some speakers were difficult to understand when they used complex terms beyond what I might have learned before.

strengths: a diversity of speakers; the frequency of seminars this spring semester was far more reasonable than fall semester'slimitations: some instructors were not particularly enthused to be speaking, nor prepared to speak to students who may not be familiar in the subject area. Lunch should be provided.
Great speakers this semester!
I enjoyed the speakers in the seminar. However, I would have liked to hear some speakers from outside of Yale.
lectures were not very interesting and they were mostly presentations we have already seen in other settings.

This class's biggest strength and weakness was that it was a largely a review of Epi 1. This was helpful in reinforcing concepts, providing alternative methods of approaching the same concepts, and taking time to go into certain topics in more detail. On the other hand, some parts were very redundant, especially if the concept had been fully understood in Epi 1.
I thought that most of the topics were interesting and usually enjoyed attending. I think a proper lunch would be nice instead of just cheese and crackers since the seminar is held at noon.

narratives.question_text: Please evaluate the instructor of this course. What are the instructor's strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might his or her teaching be improved?
comments: Instructor: Susan Mayne  Susan Mayne chooses appropriate speakers to come in from diverse academic research backgrounds, therefore making the seminars interesting
Instructor: Susan Mayne  N/A
Instructor: Susan Mayne  n/a
Instructor: Susan Mayne  n/a
Instructor: Susan Mayne  Drs. Lewis and Nunez-Smith were most relate-able speakers and arguably the most well-received
Instructor: Susan Mayne  Great

Instructor: Susan Mayne  Susan Mayne was not there all the time and when she was - she simply introduced the lecturers. She did not try to facilitate meaningful conversation between the lecturer and students.
Instructor: Susan Mayne  Susan introduced some of the speakers, but really wasn't an instructor.

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize this course for a fellow student? Would you recommend it to another student? Why or why not?
comments: Learning more about the opportunities in the public health field is definitely valuable
Hearing about the research of Yale faculty and alumni in the field of chronic disease epidemiology.
This course presents different areas of research being conducted primarily at Yale.
I particularly enjoy when a professor we're familiar with presents on something other than his or her primary research topic.
The lecture series requires no outside work and is a great way to learn about the diverse research going on at Yale and other universities.
An introduction to faculty research in CDE/SBS at Yale.
Good to explore diverse areas of public health.
This course brings in speakers from various topics in CDE/SBS to discuss their research.
bring your own lunch to hear a professor talk
Interesting speakers presenting on their public health research in epi and sbs
I would recommend this seminar course to another student.
Useful to take if concepts from Epi are shaky.

As a required aspect of SBS/CDE I think the topics are interesting, but there could be more involvement. The students come and listen and are exposed to some research ideas and opportunities, and it was nice to see what the interests are of the faculty in the department.
